abstract.p: Florence Fabricant reviews Ainsley Harriott's Meals in Minutes cookbook; recipe; photo (M)

block.p: TACKLING the recipes in ''Ainsley Harriott's Meals in Minutes'' (Dorling Kindersley, $19.95) calls for energy, concentration and dexterity. It often means doing two, three or even four things at the same time. I am highly organized in the kitchen, but this book put me to the test.

TACKLING the recipes in ''Ainsley Harriott's Meals in Minutes'' (Dorling Kindersley, $19.95) calls for energy, concentration and dexterity. It often means doing two, three or even four things at the same time. I am highly organized in the kitchen, but this book put me to the test.

Mr. Harriott, who has one television program in Britain and another filmed in New York and shown in the United States, is a chef in high gear, enlisting audience and celebrity assistants to work on salads, whip up a marinade, sear chicken and somehow assemble a dish while keeping up a steady, energetic patter.

The big surprise is that this culinary sprint is mostly worth it. Occasionally, a recipe like spicy Indian ground lamb skewers takes 10 to 15 minutes longer than Mr. Harriott's E.T.A. On the other hand, I made his pan-fried pizza in 30 minutes, not 40, as the recipe stated.

That pizza is made with a simple dough of flour, water and baking powder, which is rolled out in a circle and put in a big oiled skillet over medium heat. While the underside browns, the toppings are arranged on it. The whole thing is then run under the broiler. I've never made a pizza like that, and it was terrific.

Spicy wine-steamed mussels, fish in a Thai curry sauce, broiled cod on couscous and even an oddly appealing onion ''tarte Tatin'' to cut in wedges all worked. Chicken in a spicy cream and yogurt sauce needed more chicken or less sauce, but it was tasty and easy.

Noodle dishes, quick casseroles and stir-fries, some of which would be good with leftovers, dominate. Aside from some worthwhile crumbles and an apricot rice pudding, the dessert chapter is weak. What I found admirable is how seldom Mr. Harriott uses canned or packaged convenience foods. The purist could go further, as I did for the pizza, using a tablespoon of tomato paste from a tube instead of ketchup.

There is no mistaking Mr. Harriott's English tastes: ''mash,'' as mashed potatoes are called, reigns; so does cod. There are also clever Asian, Mexican and Cajun touches. He gives a good tip: freeze chunks of peeled ginger for easy grating.
A 20-minute Peking duck was that fast and excellent. But there was no crispy skin, so I fried strips of duck skin to tuck into the pancakes. It added less than five minutes.
QUICK PEKING DUCK Adapted from ''Ainsley Harriott's Meals in Minutes'' Time: 30 minutes
12 ounces skinless, boneless duck breast 2 tablespoons dark soy sauce 2 tablespoons honey 1 teaspoon Chinese five-spice powder

1/4 teaspoon coarse black pepper 1 teaspoon toasted sesame oil 1 garlic clove, crushed 1 tablespoon white wine vinegar 3 tablespoons plum jam or hoisin sauce Pinch dried chili flakes 8 Chinese wheat-flour pancakes 1 tablespoon sunflower or peanut oil 4 scallions, trimmed and slivered
1/2 cucumber, peeled, seeded and cut in matchsticks 1 tablespoon fresh cilantro leaves plus sprigs for garnish.
1. Halve duck breast horizontally. Then cut with the grain in thin slivers. Mix 1 tablespoon soy sauce with honey, five-spice powder and pepper, toss with duck, and set aside.

2. Heat sesame oil in small saucepan, add garlic, cook briefly, then stir in vinegar, jam, chili flakes and remaining soy sauce. Cook 2 minutes over medium heat to blend, then strain through a sieve, mashing the garlic. Set sauce aside.
3. Place pancakes on a heat-proof plate. Cover with foil. Set them on top of pan of simmering water to warm.
4. Heat sunflower or peanut oil in wok or skillet. Drain duck in sieve to remove excess marinade, add to wok, and stir-fry over high heat 2 to 3 minutes, until browned. Remove from heat.
5. Spread warm pancakes with sauce mixture. Top with strips of duck, scallion and cucumber, sprinkle with cilantro, and roll up. Garnish with cilantro sprigs, and serve.
Yield: 2 to 4 servings.
BY THE BOOK
